Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: A Mechanistic Approach to Understanding and Lowering the Overpotential for CO2 Reduction to C1 Organic Products
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF Chemical Catalysis Program supports the efforts of Professor Andrew B. Bocarsly of Princeton University to investigate the mechanisms of carbon dioxide (CO2) reduction to one carbon (C1) organic products: formic acid, formaldedhyde or methanol. In the case of methanol, a 6-electron, 6-proton reaction is required which can be undertaken using either a one-electron redox mediator or in some cases can be observed to occur via a direct CO2-surface interaction. In all cases, a complex reaction mechanism is implicated. The research group examines the rate limiting step(s) associated with the formation of formate, one of the major reaction products. Heterogeneous CO2 reduction at post-transition metal oxide interfaces, interface-free CO2 reduction using transition metal based molecular systems, and cyanogel systems for CO2 electroreduction are under study. The first two topics explore the critical question of the role of a reactive surface in the reaction pathway. To consider this question under kinetically limiting conditions leading to formate formation, the team examines anodized post transition metal electrodes. These materials are catalytic in the absence of an additional dissolved catalyst, allowing the research group to look specifically at the range of heterogeneous processes occurring directly at the electrode interface during CO2 reduction. The study is organized using periodic trends, with zinc, cadmium, indium, bismuth and lead selected as key systems. The second study attacks the problem from the opposite direction. In this study, aromatic amine catalysts are used to carry-out the reduction of CO2 in the absence of a surface. Here, advantage is taken of the photoexcited ruthenium(bipyridyl) systems, charge transfer quenched by an aromatic amine to generate CO2 reduction absent an electrode interface. The team also explores manganese complexes containing bisphosphinine (L2) ligands, in this regard. The final study uses cyanogel chemistry to both generate alloy materials that will facilitate the electrode-based studies, and to produce novel electrolytes that are known to have a high CO2 capacity.

Understanding CO2 activation is a critical chemical challenge as it contributes to the development of new fuel resources and as well as potentially lowering greenhouse gases in the environment. In addition to its pivotal role in the education of next generation electrochemical researchers, who are key to an alternate energy future, this program impacts K-12 education by providing an excellent tool for teaching both students and teachers fundamental chemical concepts using the currently topical problem of greenhouse gas control as a motivating principle. Another important aspect of the proposed program is its close affiliation with an aggressive startup company that is focused on taking this research out of the laboratory and into the real world. Demonstration scale systems that will convert CO2 into commercial chemicals are planned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One exciting approach to mitigating the levels of CO2 that are pumped into the atmosphere is to convert this compound to a more useful species. One can electrochemically convert CO2 into organic compounds that are fuels or useful starting materials (feedstocks) for polymers, plastics, or pharmaceuticals. In this way, our atmosphere can be cleared of excess carbon dioxide, and at the same time we can reduce the need to utilize fossil fuels, the main source of anthropogenic CO2. However, in order to carry out the chemical transformations needed to convert CO2 to useful products one needs catalysts that help make a specific product of interest and, more importantly, do it using a minimum of energy. Without these catalysts, one cannot carry out the chemistry envisioned in a cost effective manner. To this end, the work undertaken here considered three different types of electrochemical catalysts (electrocatalysts) for converting CO2 to more valuable compounds. The purpose of the research was not to generate systems to produce the chemical products of interest, but rather, to develop and learn about the chemistry necessary to carry out requisite chemical transformations. Using this knowledge, others could then develop detailed chemistries for the electrochemical production of fuels and feedstocks.

Three systems were investigated: (1) a manganese organometallic complex for the conversion of CO2 to CO, (2) electrodes composed of post-transition metals (indium, tin, lead, or bismuth) which can reduct CO2 to formate (formic acid), and (3) electrodes composed of transition metal alloys containing nickel and either aluminum or gallium. This final set of electrocatalysts, reported for the first time under this NSF award, are quite interesting because unlike most catalyst for the reduction of CO2, these electrocatalysts promote the formation of compounds containing multiple carbons. In this respect, this last class of catalysts generates products that are similar to fossil fuel based products. However, all three systems generate products of industrial interest.

Key findings from this study include the conclusions that hydrogen bonding interactions play a key role in the electrochemical reduction of CO2, post transition metal electrodes rely on a surface oxyhydroxide to catalyze the reduction of CO2, and nickel based alloy electrodes produce products containing carbon-carbon bonds through a mechanism that appears to first convert CO2 to CO and then transform the CO to the products of interest. To obtain these findings, we developed and utilized a set of tools that allowed us to follow the details of the reaction chemistry in real time. This included the pairing of infrared spectroscopy with electrochemical reaction conditions; a particular challenge since our chemistry is mainly carried out in water where infrared spectroscopy is difficult to undertake. Our work also led to a new measure of electrochemical efficiency that allowed us to meter simultaneously how the rate of the chemical reaction(s) of interest and the amount of driving force needed to promote the chemistry impacted the overall energy efficiency of the process. This parameter has far reaching applications that will be useful in the development of electrocatalysts in general (not just for CO2 based chemistry).

Using the concepts that we developed in this work, we were able to demonstrate improved efficiencies, stabilities, and product selectivity for the electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide to products of industrial value. We anticipate that this work will help to institutionalize a proactive means of limiting carbon dioxide emissions and encourage deployment of carbon capture technologies so that a CO2 mitigation system could be employed to create value added products. This will be attractive to both existing and new businesses. With the help of catalysts like the ones we developed, emissions reduction goals could realistically be assisted in such a way that encourages business compliance due to added profitability. We make this final statement because the work reported here and disseminated through a variety of public channels has been used by the start up company, Liquid Light Inc. amongst others in their development of industrial scale reactors for CO2 conversion.

Finally, it is noted that through this grant a dozen students carried out Ph.D. studies and are now employed in the energy and chemical sectors. The work also supported an equal number of undergraduate researchers that have either entered the workplace or sought higher education. One postdoctoral researcher has now become a professor after spending time in a governmental research laboratory. Thus, this grant has expanded the knowledge base related to CO2 chemistry both with respect to fundamental science and practical applications. At the same time, it has help train the next generation of scientists needed to meet the chemical and environmental changes facing us today and into the future.
